author: VNExplorer
title: EPHRAIM HARDCASTLE: Could Prince Andrew's financial settlement with the King be affected if his name is dragged through the mud with the publication of Jeffrey Epstein documents?
text:
The Duke of York faces an anxious New Year wait to discover if his name is to be dragged through the mud again with the US publication of previously sealed Jeffrey Epstein documents.
The Duke of York faces an anxious New Year wait to discover if his name is to be dragged through the mud again
The US publication of previously sealed Jeffrey Epstein documents is expected next month
Andrew didnâ€™t suffer any collateral damage from the Ghislaine Maxwell trial and told Charles it was now â€˜time to move onâ€™
The content could affect his settlement with the King over his finances. My source reports that the agreement between the brothers was based on assurances from Andrew that everything was now in the open (â€˜done and dustedâ€™).
He also didnâ€™t suffer any collateral damage from the Ghislaine Maxwell trial and told Charles it was now â€˜time to move onâ€™. With the Epstein file to be published next month with minimal redactions, might Andrew be sweating?
Honours committee members who decide on who gets New Year gongs are themselves replete with more than enough ironmongery.
Of the 13 members of the main committee, ten have gongs and another is a privy counsellor. The two without might reasonably expect to be rewarded soon.
Stephen Kelly is a distinguished businessman and government adviser and John Booth is chairman of the Kingâ€™s Trust and a trustee of the National Gallery.
Honours committee members who decide on who gets New Year gongs are themselves replete with more than enough ironmongery (Pictured: Cabinet Office and Whitehall street entrance)
There are also eleven sub-committees looking after honours in areas such as the arts, sport, science and communities.
Forty-seven independent members sit on these sub-committees of whom thirty-nine have honours. Small world.
John Cleese confirms the loss of his comedy mojo with his latest â€˜jokeâ€™ listing ways Hitler was preferable to Trump:
John Cleese confirms the loss of his comedy mojo with his latest â€˜jokeâ€™ listing ways Hitler was preferable to Trump
1. He fought for his country. 2. He never used a teleprompter. 3. He was nice to dogs. 4. He wrote his own books. 5. He never played golf. 6. He wasnâ€™t a big fat slob.
The inevitable media backlash prompts Cleese to backtrack: â€˜OK. Trump is a better human being than Hitler. Will you be able to sleep now?â€™
Kathy Lette mourns fellow Australian Bill Granger who has died aged 54. He presented her with a set of his cook books after she wailed that she used her smoke alarm as a timer.
Kathy Lette mourns fellow Australian Bill Granger who has died aged 54
â€˜I once rang him in a fluster, perplexed by a recipe,â€™ she recalls. â€˜What the hell is a braise?â€¦â€™Braise yourself, darlingâ€™ sounds like Australian foreplay.â€™
Australian travel writer Robyn Davidson, who so enthralled Salman Rushdie that he left his first wife Clarissa Luard and initially dedicated The Satanic Verses to her, admits she is no longer a fan. â€˜I donâ€™t read him anymore,â€™ she says.
Australian travel writer Robyn Davidson so so enthralled Salman Rushdie that he left his first wife Clarissa Luard and initially dedicated The Satanic Verses to her
â€˜I think of him as a sort of Faustian figure. Salman had that terrible need to be famous, to be seen and acknowledged.â€™ Surely not during the fatwa, Robyn?
Self-proclaimed High King of Ireland Roderic Oâ€™Connor, who has died aged 77, once had to plead with painter Francis Bacon at his luncheon table at Wheelers for the return of the handcuff keys he had used to shackle Guinness heir Garech Browne to the bar at Sohoâ€™s Colony Room Club.
Finding Garech handcuffed, Roderic roared: â€˜We all know youâ€™re fond of a drink, but this is ridiculous.â€™

author: TLN Team
title: In Flooded Nagpur, Sainagar Hires Its Own JCB - The Live Nagpur
text:
As floodwaters swamped East Nagpur and civic officials vanished from view, the residents of Sainagar didnâ€™t wait for help â€” they became the help.
With lanes submerged, homes flooded, and no emergency response in sight, locals pooled â‚¹7,000 from 12 households and hired a JCB machine themselves. â€œChildren were trapped, and elders couldnâ€™t move. We had no choice,â€ said Vijay Patil, who contributed â‚¹500. â€œWe needed action, not promises.â€
Sameer Wankhede, a local JCB operator known for responding in crises, arrived within an hour. â€œIt was chaos,â€ he said. â€œWater had no place to go. So we created one.â€ With help from residents, Sameer used the machineâ€™s bucket to unblock choked drains and carve out temporary channels to redirect floodwater into a nearby nullah.
The effort lasted over four hours. Residents like Mehnaz Begum and Suresh Joshi stood in knee-deep water, clearing slush and guiding Sameerâ€™s every move. â€œHe didnâ€™t just do his job â€” he became one of us,â€ said Joshi.
While the Nag and Pili rivers had overflowed, backflow was worsened by plastic-choked drains and zero official support. Not a single NMC team reached the area until late evening.
Teacher Sandhya Kale put it bluntly: â€œIf citizens can respond this fast, why canâ€™t the authorities?â€
Sainagar may have drained out, but the real flood was of courage, unity â€” and one JCB operator who showed up when the government didnâ€™t.

author: Josh Goeree
title: Severe winter weather causing blood donations to drop in Waterloo Region
text:
The severe winter weather in Waterloo Region has not only impacted the roads, but blood donations as well. Canadian Blood Services says they have seen hundreds of last-minute cancellations due to the poor weather. Other cities across the province that were hit by the storms, including Guelph and London, are noting donations being cancelled.
The drop in donations also means that optimal levels for blood products, such as whole blood and plasma, are down. The most recent update from Canadian Blood Services shows four blood types, including A-, B-, O+ and O- are all below the eight-day supply nationally.
Related:
Large demand for blood donations this holiday season in Waterloo Region â€˜Not a big deal,â€™ says Laurier employee logging his 70th blood donation With elective surgeries ramping up, blood donations are needed Rachael Henderson, the Community Development Manager at Canadian Blood Services, said donating during the winter is especially important because blood products are more in demand now than they have been in the last 10 years.
â€œThere has been an increase in surgeries and treatments that require blood products,â€ said Henderson. â€œThat also goes back to the fact that the population is aging and growing. So you see the number of units of blood increase that are needed.â€
Henderson adds the donation centre in Waterloo at 94 Bridgeport Rd. E. has several open appointments for those looking to donate.
Canadian Blood Services have been pushing to have 450 new donors every day this winter to help keep up with demand.
